awd_titl_txt: CRII: OAC: A Hybrid Finite Element and Molecular Dynamics Simulation Approach for Modeling Nanoparticle Transport in Human Vasculature
awd_abstract_narration:
Through nanomedicine significant methods are emerging to deliver drug molecules directly to diseased areas for cancer treatment.  Targeted drug delivery is one of the most promising approaches which relies on nanoparticles (NPs) that carry and release drugs.  The therapeutic efficacy of NP-based drug carriers is determined by the proper concentration of drug molecules at the lesion site.  NPs need to be delivered directly to the diseased tissues while minimizing their uptake by other tissues, thereby reducing the potential harm to healthy tissue.  Therefore, the design of these NPs and hence the efficacy of the targeted drug delivery could be significantly improved by understanding how the drugs carried by NPs are transported and dispersed in human body.  This project proposes a set of computational tools to model and investigate the transport and dispersion of NPs in human vasculature.  This, in turn, can provide better imaging sensitivity, therapeutic efficacy and lower toxicity of NP-based drug carriers.  The multidisciplinary nature of the project also brings together concepts from biology, engineering and computer science to educate the next generation of computational biologists, scientists and engineers. This research, thus, aligns with the NSF mission to promote the progress of science and to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare. 

The technical objective of this project is to create a hybrid finite element and molecular dynamics computational approach for modeling NP transport and adhesion in human vasculature.  The realistic geometry of vascular network and fluid dynamics of blood flow are accurately captured through the finite element model.  The microscopic interactions between NPs and red blood cells within blood flow and adhesion of NPs to vessel wall are resolved through the molecular dynamics simulation.  A robust and efficient coupling interface is built to couple the finite element and molecular dynamics solvers.  Specifically, this project aims to 1) create a multiscale and multiphysics computational model for predicting the vascular dynamics of NPs under the influence of realistic geometrical and physiochemical features of human vasculature; 2) craft an interface coupling technique that enhances computational accuracy and predictability by coupling the finite element and molecular dynamics solvers; 3) build testsuits for multiscale and multiphysics simulations for coupled solution error and convergence analysis; and 4) advance the current cyberinfrastructure to accelerate the material design process and enrich the cyber-enabled materials design community.  Such a computational method can be used to explore how the vascular dynamics of NPs will be affected by their size, shape, surface and stiffness properties, as well as complex geometry of human vasculature.  The simulation results can further guide experimentalists to design NP-mediated drug delivery platforms that optimally accumulate within diseased tissue to provide better imaging sensitivity, therapeutic efficacy and lower toxicity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The following outcomes have been achieved to address the intellectual merit and broader impacts of this project:

First, we've developed a powerful and portable simulation package called OpenFSI for simulating how fluids and structures interact. This package is highly efficient and works across various platforms. In OpenFSI, we use a lattice model (LM) to simulate the behavior of structures, which is integrated within a system called LAMMPS, achieving the same accuracy as traditional finite element analysis. For fluid flow, we use Palabos, which employs a method known as the Lattice Boltzmann method (LBM) to solve equations that describe fluid movement effectively. To connect the structure and fluid simulations, we use the immersed boundary method (IBM), which allows for flexibility in choosing different solvers for solids and fluids. The entire simulation runs within the Palabos framework, with LAMMPS acting as an external library coupled through IBM. To demonstrate OpenFSI's capabilities and accuracy, we validated the LM by simulating the bending of 2D and 3D beams in LAMMPS and comparing the results with finite element analysis. We also ran classic tests, like fluid flow around a flexible beam and a cylinder, as well as more complex scenarios, such as free-falling spheres, a flapping plate in a cross-flow, spheres passing a dam, and the movement of tiny swimmers. Additionally, we tested the efficiency of OpenFSI with a large system involving thousands of red blood cells in blood flow, finding that it scales well up to 8192 processors. In short, OpenFSI is a robust and efficient tool for solving large-scale fluid-structure interaction problems, helping us understand complex physical mechanisms.

Second, we study how tiny particles, both spherical and worm-like, move with red blood cells (RBCs) in a narrowed blood vessel that mimics a diseased microvessel. Using 3D simulations with the OpenFSI package, we examine how different shapes and sizes of these narrowings affect where the particles end up. We found that spherical particles (1 μm in diameter) tend to build up more in the narrow sections as the length and severity of the narrowing increase. This happens because the RBCs carry the spheres with them, leading to a higher concentration of particles in the narrowed area due to changes in blood flow caused by the narrowing. Worm-like particles (nanoworms) accumulate even more than spherical ones. This is because nanoworms can escape from clusters of RBCs and gather near the vessel walls. As they move along the wall, they eventually get trapped in the narrowing, increasing their concentration there. However, in extreme cases with very severe and long narrowings, RBCs cluster tightly in the center of the channel, making it harder for nanoworms to escape and resulting in similar accumulations for both nanoworms and spheres. This research could help design better nano- and micro-particles for medical uses, such as drug delivery systems for patients with narrowed blood vessels.

Third, the project has provided a platform to educate and train next-generation researchers and engineers, including graduate students, undergraduate students, and K-12 students. Students of underrepresented minorities were actively involved in the project through close interactions with the McNair Scholars Program at the University of Connecticut (UConn). A graduate-level course “Computational Nanomechanics” was offered in Spring 2023 at the University of Wisconsin-Madison (UWM). The new knowledge of blood flow simulations was introduced, and the ongoing progress of the project was shared with more than 10 graduate students. Besides, four undergraduate students have been involved in this project. They received careful mentoring and guidance through the research experience which prepared three of them to be successfully admitted to the graduate programs. Moreover, the PI group extended the impact to local K-12 students through active interactions through the UConn Explore Engineering (E2) Program, which is a one-week residential STEM summer camp for current high school sophomores and juniors. In the summer of 2019, the PI’s group together with K-12 students from the E2 program participated in an all-day outreach workshop about modeling and simulation supported by this project.


Last Modified: 06/04/2024
Modified by: Ying Li

First, we've developed a powerful and portable simulation package called OpenFSI for simulating how fluids and structures interact.
